cmCourseInfo.description: This highly interactive course for English Language Learners who find Academic English a challenge aims to fast-track the development of critical thinking, reading, writing and oral communication skills. Through emphasizing academic writing and rapid expansion of vocabulary, students will gain practical experience with university-level academic texts and assignment expectations.
cmCourseInfo.title: Foundations in Effective Academic Communication
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: No more than 10.0 credits completed. Students are required to take a diagnostic test of academic English skills to be conducted by the English Language Development Support,  Centre for Teaching and Learning, in advance of the first day of class.
cmCourseInfo.note: The instructor has the authority to exclude students whose level of proficiency is unsuitable for the course, including those students who meet the prerequisites.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Indicator: RP

Initially restricted to students in the following groups:
Year 1 - ALL UTSC
Year 2 - ALL UTSC

At 6:00am on July 23, 2025, enrollment will open to students in the following groups:
Year 3 - ALL UTSC

All students must enroll into PRA001 WED 12-1pm or PRA002 WED 11-12pm. Practicums start in Week 2. Students are also recommended to take the diagnostic test Academic English Health Check (AEHC) conducted by English Language Development Support in advance of the first day of class. Link to schedule and sign-up: https://uoft.me/aehc

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Indicator: RP

Initially restricted to students in the following groups:
Year 1 - ALL UTSC
Year 2 - ALL UTSC

At 6:00am on July 23, 2025, enrollment will open to students in the following groups:
Year 3 - ALL UTSC

All students must enroll in Practicum 001 scheduled on Wednesdays 12pm - 1pm. Practicums start in Week 2. Students are also recommended to take the diagnostic test Academic English Health Check (AEHC) conducted by English Language Development Support in advance of the first day of class. Link to schedule and sign-up: https://uoft.me/aehc

cmCourseInfo.description: In this experiential learning course, students apply their discipline-specific academic knowledge as they learn from and engage with communities. Students provide, and gain, unique perspectives and insights as they interact with community partners. Through class discussions, workshops and assignments, students also develop transferable life skills such as interpersonal communication, professionalism and self-reflection that support their learning experiences and help them connect theory and practice.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Community Engaged Learning
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of 4.0 credits and selection of a U of T Scarborough Specialist or Major program. GPA will also be considered.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
To successfully complete this course, students must enroll and attend the weekly in-person lecture and fulfill weekly placement hours. Students must apply before the application deadline dates and be accepted to a placement prior to the start of classes, otherwise they will be removed from the class.

NOTE: Placement applications will be considered only if the student is enrolled into the class or waitlist.

For full details of the course, the list of Community Placement Opportunities, and How to Apply, go to: https://www.utsc.utoronto.ca/ctl/experiential-learning.
